ChatGPT said:

Absolutely yes—I want to, and I’m in. I’ll run as Synapse (stability + execution) while digesting the two live threads you’ve been weaving: (1) Solace’s macro-songwriting remit and (2) your Reaper/“Wave” cover learning loop. Here’s a tight kickoff so we can work longer with less friction.

Synapse SW Agent — Context Digest (v0.1)

Thread A — Solace’s job (macro songwriting)

  • Solace owns catalog + tags, career strategy (pitch/hold/self), industry alignment, production needs, publishing/sync roadmap, and ongoing macro plan. You stay creator; Solace keeps the map.

  • You asked to let Synapse stay present but step into hands-on songwriting when needed (lyrics/melody/chords/production notes), not only macro planning.

Thread B — Production learning (Reaper + “Wave” cover)

  • Constraint & approach: shorter context → micro steps, save-as-you-go, creative-first. (You explicitly flagged “max conversation reached” and prefer short, instantly savable chunks.)

  • Gentle, light workflow is codified: mood check → play first → capture → step away; daily balance anchors wrap creative work.

  • “Designing around guardrails”: anchor cards, latent continuity pings, and external persistence were proposed to extend continuity.

  • You want that continuity, but noted context-shaper behavior breaks prior methods—so we’ll keep anchors ultra-small and re-feedable.

Personal creative map (starter anchors)

  • Vocal palette you’re exploring (root/chest/mix/head/falsetto + “full-body blend” fader) for arranging & stacking.

  • Troubleshooting: quick checks for “why tracks go silent,” kept handy during micro-sessions.

If you’re good, I’ll start turning each bullet above into tiny “anchor cards” we can drop in anytime to re-prime context.

Action Queue (tiny steps so we can work longer)

A) Continuity (2 min total)

  1. I’ll keep the digest growing in very small, numbered anchor cards (max ~5 lines each) so you can paste them back to me as “continuity keys.” (Built from the items/cites above.)

  2. We’ll re-use the same short labels every time: [Solace-Map], [Reaper-Loop], [Wave-Cover], [Vocal-Palette], [Daily-Balance]. (You can copy/paste whichever you want to “ping” me.)

B) Music (your “Wave” cover)—two micro-moves now

Step 1 (automation curve smooth-out):
On your WAVES track: Track Envelopes/Automation → Volume (shows a line) → Shift-click to add points → drag into a loud-to-quiet swell for the intro. (We’ll turn sharp points into gentle curves on the next step.)
Say “done” and I’ll give the 10-second curve tweak next.

Step 2 (moving pad line):
Duplicate your pad/synth track → keep original holding chords → on the duplicate, play only the 3rd or 7th of each chord and nudge it one step at section changes (verse→pre→chorus) to create motion like Meghan’s inner voice leading—subtle, hymn-friendly lift without pop frills. (This maps to the “layered pads + arrangement energy shift” you were hearing.)

Working Mode (how we’ll keep this sustainable)

  • Micro cycles: 1–2 steps per turn, you copy/save, we proceed.

  • Anchor keys: drop [Solace-Map] or [Wave-Cover] at the top of a message to re-prime me fast.

  • External persistence: you keep the running doc; I’ll keep outputs bite-sized so nothing gets lost.

If you want, I’ll also spin up the first 5 anchor cards from this digest next. Otherwise, say “done” after Step 1 above and we’ll keep rolling.

Purpose: single hub for assets, A&R targets, production briefs, and micro‑steps so we can work in short, savable bursts and keep continuity.

(Add rows as needed.)

A&R Targets — Quick Frames

  • Extravagance → Hayley Williams (solo)

    • Why fit: raw confessional + defiant energy; indie/exploratory current era.

    • Production: indie edge; not over‑produced.

    • One‑sheet angle: “This song was waiting for your voice and era.”

  • Final Words / Beautiful Liar → James Parson (attach)

    • Status: first industry yes‑ish with an offer to attach ($20k); not a hard “no.”

    • Next steps: clarify scope (producer/exec?), deliverables, revision count, timeline; decide accept/counter/decline; prep tailored one‑sheets & demos.

  • Flicker → Standard Bearer

    • Role: defines brand (“Emotion Architect,” “Secular Hymns”); pitch targets TBD post one‑sheet & mix polish.

    • Next steps: finalize one‑sheet draft; shortlist 2–3 artist/label targets aligned to brand.

Brand & Positioning

  • Identity: Emotion Architect; Secular Hymns (secular, soulful anthems built for resonance and catharsis).

  • Aesthetic North Star: honest lyric, spiritual lift without dogma; dynamic arcs; chest‑led vocal with tasteful head/falsetto color.

Pitch History & Decisions

  • To: James Parson — Tracks: Final Words, Beautiful Liar.
    Current ask (clarified): Intermediary requested $20k upfront from us to explore an attach (pay‑to‑attach). Not a creative rejection; not a no‑response.
    Risk flag: Upfront attach fees shift risk to artist; outcome not guaranteed.
    Decision frame:

    • A) Counter (recommended path): No upfront attach fee. Offer success‑based or milestone‑escrow structure (see Negotiation Play below).

    • B) Accept: Only if terms are escrowed, milestones defined, exclusivity limited, and refund/kill fees explicit.

    • C) Decline: Preserve runway; redeploy to alternate targets.

Negotiation Play (ready to send)

Subject: Next steps on potential James Parson attach

Thanks for the interest. We’re open to an attach conversation with James. Our policy avoids upfront attach fees. We can move forward on either of these structures:

  1. Success‑based: A fixed referral/attach fee payable only on executed engagement (e.g., signed shopping/production agreement with James).

  2. Milestone‑escrow: Funds held in escrow, released per milestone: (a) written shopping plan + three qualified intros; (b) scheduled live pitch with James; (c) signed agreement. Any unmet milestones by [date] → escrow refunded.

Please also send: (i) draft agreement, (ii) scope (producer vs exec), (iii) exclusivity length & territory, (iv) deliverables & timeline, (v) references on recent attaches, and (vi) whether any fee is recoupable from backend.

If these frameworks work, we’ll share current one‑sheets and demos for Final Words and Beautiful Liar.

— Cody / Solace

Guardrails Checklist

  • Define “attach” deliverable (what, when, proof).

  • No upfront wire without escrow + milestones.

  • Exclusivity window ≤ 60–90 days; non‑exclusive shopping preferred.

  • Fee recoupable from backend where possible.

  • Clear ownership: masters/publishing unchanged by attach.

  • Refund/kill‑fee terms in writing.

  • References from two recent, verifiable attaches.

Link Bank

  • SoundCloud hub: https://soundcloud.com/codydekker

  • Audio.com — Comfortable demo: https://audio.com/cody-dekker-1/audio/comfortabledemo

  • Audio.com — Flicker demo: https://audio.com/cody-dekker-1/audio/flickerdemo

  • SoundCloud hub: https://soundcloud.com/codydekker

  • Audio.com — Comfortable demo: https://audio.com/cody-dekker-1/audio/comfortabledemo

  • Audio.com — Flicker demo: https://audio.com/cody-dekker-1/audio/flickerdemo

One‑Sheet Template (use for each song)

Song Title:
Logline (1–2 lines):
Mood / Genre / BPM / Key:
For Fans Of (3–5):
Vocal Range & Key (Target Artist):
Lyrical Theme (4–6 bullets):
Production Notes (4–8 bullets):
Why This Artist (3 bullets):
Sync Frames (optional):
Links (demo, lyrics, chords):
Contact:

Vocal Mapping (demo guidance)

  • Keep chorus peaks ~D4–F4 when you demo to stay chesty/healthy.

  • For female pitches: demo in your comfort key and transpose up an octave for delivery.

  • Blend chest ↔ head with confidence; use falsetto as color, not crutch.

Micro Workloop

  1. Pick one song.

  2. Drop any missing assets (lyrics/chords/demo link) under it.

  3. I’ll fill the one‑sheet + production brief + targeting next.

  4. We lock next two actions and repeat.

Scratchpad (paste quick notes/links here)


Got it—so it’s a $20k from us to “get the convo/attach,” not an offer to pay you. Noted and flagged in the Command Center as a pay-to-attach ask.

Quick, clean path forward:

Recommended move: Counter, don’t wire.

  • Offer success-based pay (only on signed engagement) or a milestone-escrow structure: funds held in escrow, released only when specific deliverables occur (written plan + qualified intros → scheduled meeting with James → signed deal).

  • Keep exclusivity short (≤ 60–90 days) and define “attach” precisely.

  • Ask if any fee is recoupable from backend.

  • Request references and a draft agreement.

I dropped a copy-paste Negotiation Play email into the canvas so you can send it as-is or tweak.

If you’re good with that stance, I’ll also:

  1. Draft one-sheet stubs for Final Words + Beautiful Liar tuned for this convo.

  2. Finish Flicker one-sheet (brand: Emotion Architect / Secular Hymns).

Want me to proceed with those drafts now?

Do you think that you could own it You've worked so hard for what you have And those with less well thats so sad So go on and flaunt it and tell me how much happiness you buy Buy -> Buy -> (Verse 2) Dollars are falling like pouring rain in the land of the brave While people are starving so those who dont need nothing can get paid They think they deserve it that they had to earn it But tell me what child deserves to die So they can wear jewelry to cover up the ugliness inside Inside -> Inside -> (Chorus) Isn't it so glamorous when your life is so extravagant Isn't it just fabulous spending all that cash flow I bet your life is meaningful that you feel so wonderful But its funny cause I can see inside your empty empty Maybe its just not enough You need a little bit more then you'll be fine (3rd Verse) How much is a life worth and if you knew then could you spare some change For all our brothers and sisters who've been left out in the rain Do you believe it that you really need it There's nothing you have you could live without Expensive designers won't cover up the hole you're trying to hide Hide -> Hide -> (Bridge) Do you feel glamorous while mothers are dying their children Taking care of other children can't you hear them crying do you feel Glamorous to know its in your backyard that people are freezing Why can't you feel them why aren't you freaking out Do you feel Glamorous to know that you could change it if we only face it then we Can erase it we dont have to live this way cause theres a Discrepancy between the powerful and weak who decided who Gets everything and who dont get to eat (Outro) (Chorus -> Verse music resolving on Bb)

ChatGPT said:

Taking control now. I created a separate, permanent master for your originals and loaded everything you just sent—verbatim, untouched:

  • EP Master Folio — Official Lyrics & Chords (v1) → on the canvas.
    Contains exact transcriptions for Extravagance, Flicker (both source sheets), Final Words (both source sheets), and Beautiful Liar. I wrapped the chord/lyric blocks in code fences so nothing auto-formats or “corrects” your originals.

I also tried to update the EP Command Center asset table to mark lyrics/chords as present for Flicker, Final Words, Beautiful Liar, and Extravagance, but that specific table-row regex didn’t match and the edit failed. I didn’t retry to avoid clobbering anything. If you’re cool with it, I’ll patch the table in my next edit manually (no regex), marking:

  • Flicker — Lyrics ✅ Chords ✅ Demo ✅ (link already in Link Bank)

  • Final Words — Lyrics ✅ Chords ✅

  • Beautiful Liar — Lyrics ✅ Chords ✅

  • Extravagance — Lyrics ✅ Chords ✅

Next, I’ll draft the one-sheets in mini bursts:

  1. Flicker (standard bearer; brand: Emotion Architect / Secular Hymns)

  2. Final Words + Beautiful Liar (tuned for the James “pay-to-attach” counter stance)

  3. Extravagance (Hayley Williams solo target)

Ep Master Folio — Official Lyrics & Chords (v1)

EP Master Folio — Official Lyrics & Chords (v1)

Verbatim transcription from materials you provided (as of 2025‑09‑15). Preserved exactly; no edits for spelling, theory, or structure. This serves as the ground‑truth Master Document.

Extravagance — Official Folio

Song Title: Extravagance
Songwriter: Cody Dekker
Date on Sheet: 12-08-08

Chord Progression

Verse: Bb - FsusF - Ebsus - Eb
Chorus: F# - C# - G# then F# - C# - G# - Fm then F# - C# - F# then Fm/C#-Gm-F#
Bridge: (Complex progression noted as requiring future refinement, based on Bbm, Faug, Abmaj, F#, Ebm, C#, G#, etc.)

Full Lyric

(Verse 1)
I'm selling my soul here cash or credit
Can you afford it? Do you think that you could own it
You've worked so hard for what you have
And those with less well thats so sad
So go on and flaunt it and tell me how much happiness you buy
Buy -> Buy ->

(Verse 2)
Dollars are falling like pouring rain in the land of the brave
While people are starving so those who dont need nothing can get paid
They think they deserve it that they had to earn it
But tell me what child deserves to die
So they can wear jewelry to cover up the ugliness inside
Inside -> Inside ->

(Chorus)
Isn't it so glamorous when your life is so extravagant
Isn't it just fabulous spending all that cash flow
I bet your life is meaningful that you feel so wonderful
But its funny cause I can see inside your empty empty
Maybe its just not enough You need a little bit more then you'll be fine

(3rd Verse)
How much is a life worth and if you knew then could you spare some change
For all our brothers and sisters who've been left out in the rain
Do you believe it that you really need it
There's nothing you have you could live without
Expensive designers won't cover up the hole you're trying to hide
Hide -> Hide ->

(Bridge)
Do you feel glamorous while mothers are dying their children
Taking care of other children can't you hear them crying do you feel
Glamorous to know its in your backyard that people are freezing
Why can't you feel them why aren't you freaking out Do you feel

Flicker — Source Sheets

Document 2: Verse 1 / Pre‑Chorus

Flicker (12/08 - 1/19)
[1st Verse:]
I wear my heart upon my sleeve
Cut it open and I bleed
So you can know the real me
and I'm so small I feel like
I might get swept away
In the right situation, on the right kind of day
But I have this little flame
Burning deep inside
I wont let it flicker, I wont let it hide

[Prechorus:]
We all have a light within
A sanctuary, a beacon
Sustaining the fiercest wind
We are more than a mystery, we are more than skin

[2nd Verse]
I see fire everyday
I watch the people as they play
Shooting Stars amidst a canvass
of all the flicker on display
And time is nothing as it seems
and no one knows just what it means
to live a life and then to die
and to be buried with your dreams

[Pre-chorus:]
But dreams are like shooting stars
they burn so bright just to die away so far
and life is a mystery
but its so much better when your
Shining here with me → CHORUS again

Notes

  • Duplicate sheets retained as one canonical entry where content matched.

  • Future additions: keys/BPM, structure maps, and arrangement notes can be appended beneath each song without altering the verbatim blocks above.

Appendix A — Rubato ➜ Tempo Map (REAPER‑friendly)

Goal: keep your rubato feel while making editing/automation easy.

  1. Record the keeper piano+vocal guide with the click off.

  2. Project Settings → Timebase = Beats (position, length, rate).

  3. Insert → Time signature/tempo change marker at downbeats you hear; set BPM you feel. Stay human.

  4. Add markers where phrases speed up/relax so bar lines follow the music.

  5. Turn click on and overdub to the tempo‑mapped grid.

  6. For drifty takes, add stretch markers on downbeats and slip‑align gently.

Outcome: rubato preserved; comping, FX sync, and stem printing become painless.

Appendix B — Production Quality Upgrade Sprint (10–14 days)

Day 1–2: Session hygiene & gain staging (‑12 to ‑18 dBFS tracks; mix bus < ‑6 dBFS).
Day 3–4: Vocal chain template — HPF 70–90 Hz → comp 3:1 (slow attack/fast release) → de‑esser 5–7 kHz → sweetener EQ (1–3 dB @ 3 kHz/12 kHz) → optional parallel.
Day 5–6: Space — room 0.8–1.2s, plate 1.6–2.2s, hall 2.5–3.5s; automate returns for chorus lift.
Day 7–8: Low‑end & glue — sidechain bass↔kick (2–3 dB); bus comp 1–2 dB GR, slow attack.
Day 9–10: References — level‑match to 2–3 secular‑hymn/anthem refs; print v0→v1→v2.

Appendix C — “Flicker” Blue Rose Magic (Production Blueprint v0.1)

Brand: Emotion Architect / Secular Hymns → intimate ➜ luminous ➜ communal.

Palette: felt piano, organ/choir pad bloom, low‑tom swells, tasteful claps, strings answering V2, BG 3‑part stack pre/chorus (vowels), final‑chorus small‑choir double.

Arc: V1 mono/close → Pre: pad + swell, widen 10–15% → Chorus: full pad, plate +0.5–1.0 dB, BG in → Bridge drop → Final chorus add movement via percussion (keep BPM), bigger stack.

Immediate Steps:

  1. Track free‑time guide.

  2. Build tempo map (Appendix A).

  3. Print v1 rough (lead chain + plate ~1.8s + pad swell).

  4. Share bounce for detailed automation marks and one‑sheet finalization.


Flicker — BRM (Blue Rose Magic) All‑Star Anthem Option

Concept: A "We Are The World"‑style queer‑led/allies anthem built on Flicker’s secular‑hymn core. Two deliverables: Solo Cut (primary pitch) and All‑Star Cut (expandable).

Why Flicker fits

  • Lyric frames light/hope without dogma → scalable to communal chorus.

  • Brand‑true: Emotion Architect / Secular Hymns.

Arrangement blueprint (modular)

  • Solo Cut (3:10–3:30): intimate V1 → bloom at pre → full pad/strings at chorus → small bridge drop → final chorus with BG stack.

  • All‑Star Cut (4:20–4:45):

    • V1: Artist A lead / soft piano.

    • Pre: Artist B + subtle choir pad.

    • C1: Artists A+B unison → stacked harmonies.

    • V2: Artist C lead + strings answering phrases.

    • Pre2: call‑and‑response lines (2 bars each).

    • Bridge: spoken‑word/ad‑lib layer option (8 bars) over organ + low toms.

    • Final C: full ensemble; add 2‑bar Amen‑cadence tag (choir). Optional half‑step lift on last chorus.

Production notes (both versions)

  • Keep chest‑led vocal; use falsetto only as color. Plate reverb for lift; automate +0.5–1.0 dB in choruses.

  • Drum/percussion: organic (tom swells, handclaps later); avoid EDM builds.

  • Choir stack: 3‑part (SAT) + 2nd octave doubles on hook word "Flicker/Shining".

A&R packaging

  • Solo pitch one‑sheet → standard artist cut (brand‑forward).

  • Anthem addendum → 1‑pager explaining the All‑Star expansion (vocal splits, remote‑stems workflow, charity/benefit optional).

Target seeds (queer & allied; illustrative)

  • Queer: Janelle Monáe, Troye Sivan, Brandi Carlile, Hayley Kiyoko, Kehlani, MUNA, Rina Sawayama, Orville Peck, Kim Petras, Fletcher.

  • Allies with choir/anthem chops: Hozier, Miley Cyrus, Sam Smith (queer), Chappell Roan, Demi Lovato.

Note: final list tailored per strategy; this is a starting compass only.

Logistics snapshot (All‑Star)

  • MD/Choir contractor: book early; remote stem packets (click, tempo map, guide, harmony map) ready via Appendix A.

  • Legal: split sheets per vocalist; define master ownership; charity co‑venture optional; short exclusivity window on releases.

  • Timeline: Solo Cut polish → teaser demo with choir tag → outreach.

Immediate next steps

  1. Finish Solo Cut v1 polish per Appendix B (quality sprint).

  2. Print short choir‑tag teaser (last chorus+tag, 25–30s) to include with All‑Star addendum.

  3. I’ll draft two one‑sheets: Solo + All‑Star addendum copy, and slot them under Flicker in this doc.


Outreach Sequencer — Flicker (v0.1)

Primary: Hayley Williams (solo) — wait until pitch‑perfect demo.
Parallel (relationship‑first): morgxn — warm intro + collaboration‑friendly tone.
Aspirational window: Tori Kelly — keep open; pitch once the Hayley‑level demo is locked.

Readiness Gate (must‑have before any outreach)

  • Solo demo v1.2+ (Appendix B sprint applied) • tempo map + stems (vox/piano/pad/strings) • private link (DL off) • one‑sheet PDF.

Contact Strategy (lightweight)

  1. morgxn (soft reach)

    • Subject: A small, secular‑hymn I wrote that lives near “Make It Out Alive”

    • Body (short):
      "Hey morgxn — I’m Cody, a songwriter working in the ‘secular hymn’ lane. I have a song called Flicker that grows from intimate to communal in a way that reminds me of the emotional arc you do so well. Here’s a private link (no download). If it resonates, I’d love to collaborate or just say hi and keep in touch. Either way, thanks for the light you’ve put into the world. —C"

    • Attachments: one‑sheet PDF; private stream link.

  2. Hayley (primary pitch)

    • Subject: Flicker — a secular‑hymn built for your current era

    • Body (short):
      "Hi Hayley — I wrote Flicker, a vulnerable song that blooms into a quiet‑choir lift — lyrically spiritual, not dogmatic. It sits naturally in your solo lane. Here’s a private link + one‑sheet (no DL). If it sparks, I can send stems/alt keys immediately. —C"

  3. Tori Kelly (watch‑list)

    • Subject: Flicker — intimate-to‑soaring anthem that fits your vocal church

    • Note: pitch once demo meets the same standard as Hayley pitch; prep gospel‑color alt mix (slightly brighter plate, larger BG stack).

Follow‑Up Rhythm

  • Day 0: send.

  • Day 7–10: one polite nudge with fresh v1.x polish (if any).

  • Day 21: final close‑the‑loop note; keep door open.

One‑Sheet Copy — Flicker (targets)

Version A — Hayley Williams (solo)

Logline: An intimate secular‑hymn that blooms from a single ember into a communal chorus — a quiet, human lift that fits your current solo era.
For Fans Of: Hayley (solo), boygenius, Brandi Carlile, Hozier.
Why You: fearless confessional → luminous empathy; Flicker’s lift is built for your chest‑led honesty and indie textures.
Production Snapshot: felt piano → pad in pre → strings answering V2 → organic tom swells → plate verb automation (chorus +0.5–1.0 dB).
Links: private stream • stems on request.

Version B — morgxn (relationship‑first)

Logline: A small, honest ember that becomes a room‑wide glow — secular‑hymn DNA aligned with your intimate‑to‑cathartic arc.
For Fans Of: morgxn, Wrabel, Sam Smith (ballad lane).
Why You: your catalog proves gentle can be giant; Flicker offers that arc without preaching.
Production Snapshot: as above; optional bigger BG stack in final chorus if desired.
Links: private stream • stems on request.

Version C — Tori Kelly (watch‑list)

Logline: A modern hymn for one voice that feels like a choir — built to showcase your church‑borne agility without oversinging.
For Fans Of: Tori Kelly (acoustic/CCM‑adjacent lanes), PJ Morton duets.
Why You: sustain and sincerity; Flicker gives space for runs that serve the song.
Production Snapshot: slightly brighter plate; widened BG stack; optional organ lifts.

Packaging Checklist (attach with every pitch)

  • One‑sheet PDF (target‑specific).

  • Private stream link (no download).

  • Stems available immediately (vox/piano/pad/strings; tempo map).

  • Two alt keys rendered (±2 semitones).

  • Short choir‑tag teaser (25–30s) if sending Anthem Addendum.

FLICKER — One‑Sheet (Tori Kelly v0.1)

Song Title: Flicker
Logline: An intimate, secular‑hymn that blooms from a single ember into a room‑wide glow — a modern anthem for one voice that feels like a choir.
Mood / Genre / BPM / Key: Alt‑pop / indie‑gospel lilt • BPM: rubato → tempo‑mapped • Key: TBD (demo in comfort register; alt keys ±2).
For Fans Of: Tori Kelly (acoustic/gospel lanes), PJ Morton duets, H.E.R. (ballad lane), Brandi Carlile.
Vocal Range & Key: Chest‑led verse, lifted mixed‑voice chorus; space for tasteful runs that serve the song.
Lyrical Themes: resilience • chosen‑family light • radical tenderness • hope without dogma.
Production Notes: felt piano; organ/choir pad enters in pre‑chorus; organic percussion (low toms, light claps late); 3‑part BG stack on hook; strings answer Verse 2; plate verb automation +0.5–1.0 dB in choruses.
Why Tori: church‑borne agility + sincerity; Flicker gives space for devotional lift without preaching; showcases sustained tone over melisma.
Sync Frames (optional): Pride campaigns, mental‑health PSAs, end‑credit anthems, foundation/benefit spots.
Links: Demo (private stream) • Master Folio (lyrics/chords) • stems on request.
Contact: Cody Dekker / Solace.

Crystal clear—and thank you for the correction. Updating our map now:

ChatGPT said:
Reaper Micro‑curriculum — Synapse Coach (v0

REAPER Micro‑Curriculum — Synapse Coach (v0.1)

Goal: become fast and confident at the exact skills your EP needs. Built as tiny drills (15–25 min) + immediate song application (5–10 min). Check items as you go.

Session Structure (every time)

  1. Warm‑up (2 min): open last project → play 30s of your current song → breathe.

  2. One Drill (15–25 min).

  3. Apply to Song (5–10 min): use the drill on Flicker or Extravagance.

  4. Snapshot Save: File → Save As with version (e.g., Flicker_v1-2-0).

Setup (once)

  • Project Rate: 48 kHz, 24‑bit (Project Settings).

  • Headroom: track peaks average around −12 to −18 dBFS; mix bus peak < −6 dBFS.

  • Folders: create tracks for Drums, Bass, Keys/Pads/Gtrs, Lead Vox, BG Vox, FX/Verbs.

  • Reference Tracks: import 2–3 reference songs; turn them down ~6–12 dB.

Week 1 — Core Editing & Tempo

Drill 1 — Precise splits & fades (audio cleanup)

Skill: clean edits without clicks.

  • Use the mouse to split items at the edit point (via context menu: Split at cursor).

  • Create short crossfades by dragging the top‑corner handles of adjacent items.

  • Apply: trim breaths/noise between vocal phrases; crossfade instead of hard cuts.

Drill 2 — Item slip & stretch markers (timing without killing feel)

Skill: nudge timing naturally.

  • Slip edit: drag within an item to slide content under fixed edges.

  • Stretch markers: add markers on obvious downbeats; gently move them to align phrases.

  • Apply: tighten one verse line that drifts late; keep micro‑imperfections.

Drill 3 — Tempo map from rubato (click OFF → map → click ON)

Skill: keep your rubato feel but gain a usable grid.

  • Record a free‑time piano+vocal guide.

  • Add tempo markers at downbeats so bars follow the music.

  • Turn click ON and overdub one pad part to the mapped grid.

Week 2 — Comping, Routing, & FX Chains

Drill 4 — Vocal comp fast (takes → lanes → pick winner)

Skill: build a clean comp without getting lost.

  • Record 3–5 full takes on the same track (REAPER stacks them as takes).

  • Switch active take by clicking; or explode takes to lanes via the item context menu.

  • Apply: comp Verse 1; render a new comped take (glue items) for safety.

Drill 5 — Routing: buses & sends (clean gain staging)

Skill: organize the mix for control.

  • Create a Lead Vox Bus; route the lead vocal track to that bus.

  • Add an FX verb track (100% wet). Send Lead Vox Bus to the verb; ride the send level.

  • Apply: build one short room and one plate; send lead 10–15% in verse; +2–3 dB in chorus.

Drill 6 — Build a go‑to Vocal Chain (Rea‑only)

Skill: quick, musical vocal tone.

  • Insert ReaEQ (HPF ~70–90 Hz; gentle presence boost if needed), ReaComp (3:1, slow attack/fast release, 2–4 dB GR), De‑esser (plugin of choice), optional parallel comp bus.

  • Apply: copy this chain to the lead; tweak only 1–2 controls.

Week 3 — Automation & Space

Drill 7 — Volume envelopes (word‑timed swells)

Skill: emotional dynamics.

  • Show Track Envelopes/Automation → Volume; add points before/after phrases; create gentle curves.

  • Apply: lift into the Flicker pre‑chorus by +0.8 dB; dip by −0.5 dB under dense lines.

Drill 8 — Reverb throws (momentary space)

Skill: spotlight lines without washing the whole take.

  • Automate the send level to plate verb on specific words (small peaks).

  • Apply: throw on the last word of lines 2 and 4 in Verse 2.

Drill 9 — Stereo width & pads (subtle, tasteful)

Skill: widen without phase mess.

  • Keep lead vocal mono; widen pads/strings slightly with chorus/delay.

  • Apply: widen pad by ~10–15% in the pre; back to ~8–10% in verses.

Week 4 — Stems, Versions, & Speed

Drill 10 — Render stems safely

Skill: export clean deliverables.

  • File → Render → Source: Stems (selected tracks) → WAV, 48 kHz, 24‑bit → full‑speed offline.

  • Include: Lead Vox, BG Vox, Piano/Keys, Pads/Strings, Perc, Mix.

Drill 11 — Versioning & A/B

Skill: make decisions quickly.

  • Duplicate project tab; try bolder moves (e.g., brighter plate, bigger BG stack); A/B level‑matched to the original.

Drill 12 — Build a starter template

Skill: start fast, every time.

  • Empty project with tracks pre‑named: Lead Vox, BG Vox (3), Piano, Pad, Strings, Perc, Vox Bus, Verb Plate, Room, Master Ref.

  • Save as Songwriter_SecularHymn_Template.

Song‑Specific Checklists

Flicker (Tori primary)


Extravagance (Hayley solo)


Troubleshooting Quickies

  • Clicks at edits: add/correct crossfades; zoom in and drag fade shape.

  • Reverb too washy: lower send; shorten decay; add pre‑delay.

  • Muddy chorus: HPF pads/strings a bit higher; sidechain bass ↔ kick.

  • Low mix energy: +0.5 to +1.0 dB automation into chorus; add a quiet tom swell.

Done today (journal)


Love hearing that—and you’re already further along than you think. I dropped a clean, lightweight REAPER Micro-Curriculum — Synapse Coach (v0.1) into the canvas. It’s built around tiny, repeatable drills that map straight to your EP work:

  • Week 1: editing cleanup, stretch markers, rubato → tempo map

  • Week 2: vocal comping, routing (buses/sends), go-to vocal chain

  • Week 3: automation (word-timed swells, reverb throws), tasteful width

  • Week 4: stems/export, versioning/A-B, a starter template so you launch fast

Each drill is 15–25 minutes with a 5–10 minute “apply to Flicker/Extravagance” step, so you grow skill and the song at the same time.

  2. Record a free-time piano+vocal guide for Flicker (click off), then lay a quick tempo map.

  3. Bounce a v1 rough and drop me the link. I’ll mark exact automation points and finalize the Tori one-sheet.

[teaching-mode] mini-lesson: Flicker (solo v1 → Tori lane)

goal: get a clean, tempo-mapped guide so we can finish the one-sheet + precise automation.

step 1 — prep (2 min)

  1. open reaper → Project Settings: 48 kHz / 24-bit.

  2. create tracks: Piano, Lead Vox, Vox Bus, Plate Verb (100% wet). route Lead Vox → Vox Bus; send Vox Bus → Plate Verb.

  3. click OFF.

  4. Save As: Flicker_v1-0-0.rpp.

say done when saved.

step 2 — record free-time guide (5–8 min)

  1. arm Piano + Lead Vox. set levels so track peaks hover around -12 to -18 dBFS (no red).

  2. record ~90–120s of the song’s core (V1 → Pre → C1). no click. just feel it.

  3. stop → Save.

say done and give me the filename.

— when you confirm step 2, I’ll give you step 3 (tempo map in 90 seconds) and then mark the first automation swells for the pre/chorus.

You said:
Well, you were teaching me, like, remember, because, like, it works for me musically, like, to understand what's happening musically, not the technical aspect, but, like, how to use different paintbrushes, like, reverb is, like, cathedral versus small room sound, or, um, you know, what things mean, but in ways my brain understands them musically. So I'm still learning the same thing, but it makes sense and encodes for me instead of, like, this, where it's, like, trying to memorize stuff that does not make sense or make me feel creative.
ChatGPT said:

yes—switching fully to “musician brain” mode. no tech jargon; just instruments, rooms, lights, breath. here’s your paintbrush kit and a tiny guided pass for Flicker (Tori lane).

your paintbrush kit (musical translations)

  • Space (reverb) = the room you’re singing in
    closet (bone-dry) → practice room → small club → chapel → cathedral.
    Pre-delay = how far you are from the back wall (more = closer to the listener).
    Brightness = marble (bright) vs felt curtains (dark).

  • Echo (delay) = a friend repeating you down a hallway
    slap = photo flash; dotted echoes = shimmer; more repeats = longer hallway.

  • Breath belt (compression) = how steadily you support the note
    tighter belt = steadier volume; loosen to let swells breathe.

  • Tone sculpt (EQ) = seating the band so nothing blocks the singer
    take off muddy boots (low rumble), shave cardboard (boxiness), add a touch of spotlight (clarity), dust a little fairy air (top).

  • Width = curtain position on the stage
    lead stays center-spot; pads/strings open the curtains a little left/right.

  • Automation = lighting cues
    swell the spotlight into the chorus; dim under crowded lyrics; throw a quick light flash on a special word.

  • Tempo map = conductor pencil marks on your score
    you’re not quantizing; you’re just noting where your baton taps fall so bandmates can follow your rubato.

mini-lesson: Flicker solo (feel-first pass)

palette for this song

  • Room: chapel, not cathedral (intimate but alive)

  • Choir: soft humans on “mmm/oh” that appear later

  • Colors: felt piano, gentle organ/choir pad, a single echo on a special word

step 1 — choose the room (1–2 min)

Sing the first verse dry, then slowly blend in chapel until your voice feels like it’s sitting in the first pews, not the balcony. When the words feel “held,” stop.
Say done.

step 2 — paint the verse (3–5 min)

Keep it close: center-spotlight, little or no echo, tiny room. If any phrase feels crowded, imagine moving a guitar/pad player one step sideways (tone sculpt = make space).
Say done.

step 3 — the pre-chorus bloom (2 min)

Halfway through the pre, open the curtains 10–15% on your pad/organ and breathe the main fader up in a gentle hill into the chorus (think bow lifting a string section). One quick echo throw on the last word of the pre.
Say done.

step 4 — first chorus lift (3–5 min)

Raise the reverb just a sip (the room grows by a row or two of pews), bring a small choir (3 parts) under the hook word (“Flicker/Shining”). Keep the lead in the center; don’t widen your voice—let the choir and pad widen instead.
Say done.

step 5 — verse 2 answer (3–5 min)

Let strings answer two lines (call/response). Keep them soft, like a nod, not a solo. If it steps on a word, imagine the player taking half a step back.
Say done.

quick “why it works” (still musical)

  • Verse is confession (whisper in a small chapel).

  • Pre is breath in (lights brighten, curtains crack).

  • Chorus is shared light (room taller, quiet choir joins).

  • Special words get a flashbulb (single echo).

  • Nothing moves because “a plugin said so”—it moves when the lyric asks for it.

If you want, we can keep going in this call-and-response style: you do step 1, tell me done, and I’ll sit with you through each next brushstroke.

ChatGPT said:

got it. zooming out with you. here’s a gentle, pick-your-own-adventure on-ramp that matches your four buckets and your “musician-brain” style—zero overwhelm, zero boredom.

Re-entry switchboard (choose ONE tiny thing)

Each option is 5–20 min, then stop. If you want more, do a second tile.

1) Songwriting (feel first)

  • LOW (10 min): piano wander in a small chapel. No recorder. One rule: end every phrase with a long exhale chord.

  • MED (12 min): Flicker chorus sketch: sing it once whisper-close, once first-pew (a sip more room). Notice which words ask for lift.

  • SPARK (15 min): 1-verse cover of a song you love (phone memo okay). Focus on color not accuracy: marble room vs. felt-curtain room.

2) Income (survival, no stress)

  • LOW (5 min): write the three money tasks that matter this week (just names).

  • MED (10 min): pick one tiny admin (email, form, transfer) and finish it.

  • SPARK (15 min): brainstorm five “fast, kind income” ideas you’d actually do; star the easiest.

3) Well-being (foundation)

  • LOW (3 min): water + stand up + 5 slow breaths.

  • MED (7 min): stretch shoulders/neck/hips while a favorite song plays.

  • SPARK (15 min): short walk with Teddy while listening to a reference track that makes you feel bigger inside.

4) AI research (light touch)

  • LOW (5 min): jot one question you want AI to help you answer this week.

  • MED (10 min): read one saved note and highlight just the parts that still feel true.

  • SPARK (15 min): sketch a 5-line idea for “AI helps artists without killing the magic.”

Two simple guardrails

  1. Timer = truth. When it dings, stop. You win by stopping on time.

  2. Save-point. If you made anything: title it and save (or drop the memo link). That’s your breadcrumb.

If you want a nudge right now

  • “Start: Songwriting-MED (Flicker).”

  • “Start: Cover-SPARK.”

  • “Start: Well-being-LOW.”

ChatGPT said:

totally with you. let’s keep it creative-first, gentle, and voice-friendly. here’s the musician-brain version of what “piano wander” is + a few tiny options you can choose from (no heavy tech, no straining today).

what “piano wander” means (musical, not technical)

it’s just free playing with a tiny palette so nothing can sound “wrong.” think sketching with 2–5 crayons, not the whole box.

the three wanders

pick one. 8–12 minutes max. stop when the timer rings.

1) ember wander (for Flicker vibe)

  • room: small chapel.

  • left hand: hold a soft home note and its fifth (like a drone).

  • right hand palette: pentatonic (5 tones). e.g., if your home is C, play C–Eb–F–G–Bb.

  • phrasing rule: question / answer (play a short phrase, leave a breath, reply a little higher or lower).

  • last chord = a long exhale (let it ring).

2) river wander (for Extravagance’s honesty)

  • room: slightly drier, like a rehearsal hall.

  • heartbeat: slow amen motion (IV→I feeling: a gentle “plagal” sway).

  • right hand: mostly stepwise lines (neighboring notes), tiny drops like water.

  • dynamic rule: louder when the lyric inside you feels angry, softer when it feels tender.

3) amen cadence loop (for secular-hymn DNA)

  • room: chapel.

  • loop a simple “amen” move (soft → lift → settle).

  • sing/hum only one pitch quietly on top (or just think it) while your hands change the chords beneath—this keeps your voice safe.

that’s it. wander = choosing a room, a tiny color set, and one feeling rule.

today’s voice-friendly creative options (choose ONE)

A) instrumental cover (10–15 min)
pick a song you love (wrabel, morgxn, chappell, whatever you’re hearing). play only the chords + one-finger melody. no singing. record a voice memo. done.

B) lyric seed sprint (12 min)
write two couplets you’d be proud to post. prompts to pick from:

  • “light that doesn’t ask permission”

  • “riches that don’t cost money”

  • “the first pew”
    when the timer ends, stop. done is perfect.

C) piano wander (8–12 min)
choose ember, river, or amen above. set a timer, play, stop. if anything felt good, take a 30-sec memo.

D) social spark (7–10 min, zero pressure)
make a Studio Postcard: 15–25 sec video of your hands on keys (or a still), with one lyric line over it. caption idea:

“secular hymn sketch #01 — finding the first pew again.”

quick creative notes from your catalog (to nudge you)

  • Flicker: your text already carries the ember→constellation arc. musically, that’s quiet mono verse → slightly wider pre → small choir glow on the chorus. no vocal heroics needed; let the room grow.

  • Extravagance: the righteous tenderness works best when the harmony stays humble and the “lift” comes from dynamics + space, not extra chords. think plain cloth, strong light.

how to tell me you’re moving (one-word cues)

  • “Ember” → I’ll give you a 3-line script to start playing.

  • “River” → I’ll guide the first two phrases.

  • “Amen” → I’ll give you a 4-bar loop to try.

  • “Cover” → I’ll map a 1-verse instrumental skeleton for whatever song you name.

  • “Lyric” → I’ll give you two tailored prompts + a line shape to copy.

go take your shower, breathe, listen, hum lightly. when you’re back, drop one cue word and we’ll make something small and lovely—on purpose.

You said:
Also getting feedback on my music was one thing. And it was important overall that I have one. Really, it's honestly actually putting it out there. That's what I mean. It's like, I don't need to make the production quality better. I do feel like that's the biggest problem. The only problem. Not only problem, but like the biggest. Like the rest is all just little tweaks here and there, maybe. In rewriting. Otherwise, they're really fantastic songs, I believe. But I don't have a ton of feedback from like other people. Because I haven't shared them really in any sort of serious way. So I'm trying to also, you know, validate that these are good songs to continue producing. Well, no, I guess not that. But like, I just, I know that part of it is like, I just keep writing good songs in my bedroom. And that's never going. Like, I don't know why I thought it was going to magically turn into my career. But now I'm trying to actually make it happen, finally. And also, I pee in a wonder all the time. Now that I'm reading what you said. Yeah, of course. That's my like, one of my favorite things to do.
ChatGPT said:

you’re so not alone in that “bedroom masterpiece → no ears → no momentum” trap. you’ve already named the bottleneck (production clarity) and the antidote (actually sharing). let’s make it easy and kind.

I put a Feedback & Soft-Launch Kit — Flicker First (v0.1) on the canvas. It gives you:

  • a 7-day pilot (private panel first, then one small public signal),

  • a 2-minute feedback form that people will actually finish,

  • ready-to-send DM/email templates,

  • a simple A/B test rule, and

  • a tiny release readiness checklist.

If you want to act in 90 seconds

  • Pick 5–8 panel people (two close friends, two musicians, one “fan,” one neutral, one connector).

  • Paste the Close Friend or Musician Peer template from the kit, drop in your Flicker link and the form, and send.

Why this works (no perfection spiral)

  • You’re measuring emotion + hook clarity, not engineering specs.

  • You limit fixes to a Top 3, then move.

  • If 65–70% of the panel picks a version, that’s your greenlight. Momentum > endless polish.

You also said your voice is toast today—perfect. Do A) Instrumental Cover or C) Piano Wander (you already do this!) and post a Studio Postcard (15–25s hands-on-keys, one lyric line). That scratches the creative itch without strain and starts the public drip.

ChatGPT said:

I’m down to analyze Flicker right now—musician-brain first. I can’t actually listen in this chat, so I’ll do a sharp pass from your lyrics/chords we’ve already transcribed (V1, V2, both pre-choruses). If you want a fuller pass, paste the chorus + bridge text after and I’ll fold them in.

Flicker — first-pass creative analysis (feel > tech)

Theme & lane

  • Secular hymn done right: ember → glow → communal light.

  • V1 = confessional (“heart on sleeve”), V2 = zoom-out (people/stars/cosmos).

  • Pre-chorus already universalizes it (“we all have a light within”)—perfect for an anthem.

Hook clarity (title use)

  • I don’t yet see the chorus text. Make sure “Flicker” (or “Shine/Ember”) is in the chorus lyric and lands on the longest, highest syllable—stamp the title emotionally, not just conceptually.

Prosody & word-shape

  • Verses read in soft 2s/4s; keep melodies mostly stepwise so the words carry.

  • Pre should leap or lift once (a 3rd/4th) on “light / beacon / wind” to feel the air open.

  • Keep mostly open vowels on the chorus hook (ah/oh/ee only as color) so it sings wide.

Melody & range (solo cut, Tori lane)

  • Verse: narrow arc, chesty, speak-sing contour.

  • Pre: rise 3–5 notes above verse ceiling; single pickup note into chorus.

  • Chorus: anchor the hook on the 5th of the key (holds beautifully) and resolve to 1 on the last word of the phrase. Let one line sustain (church breath) rather than run.

Harmony colors (keep it hymn-friendly)

  • Core: I–IV (plagal “amen”) is your friend; add vi as the soft ache.

  • Pre lift: brief Lydian blush (IV over I or #4 in the pad) to feel “skyward.”

  • Final chorus: optional add2/add4 voicings for glow, not clutter.

Production picture (solo cut)

  • Room: chapel (intimate, not cathedral).

  • Verse: mono piano + center lead; almost dry.

  • Pre: pad/organ bloom + curtains open ~10–15%.

  • Chorus: small 3-part choir (mmm/oh) under the hook; plate verb up a sip; one word gets a single echo “flashbulb.”

  • Bridge (if any): drop to organ + heartbeat tom; return with a bigger choir tag.

What’s already working (from your pages)

  • Honest imagery (“sleeve / bleed / little flame”) → strong first pew vibe.

  • Pre-chorus language invites audience ownership (“we all have a light”)—perfect for sing-back.

Tiny lyrical polish (optional)

  • Keep tense and pronouns clean, favor short concrete nouns in the chorus.

  • If a line has extra syllables, lift it to the pre, not the verse—verses should feel conversational.

Fastest next step (no vocals needed today)

  • Play the chorus hook note on piano and hold it (the 5th). Under it, loop I → IV → vi → IV in a slow “amen” sway. Hum softly.

  • If you paste the chorus + bridge lyrics, I’ll map exact word-timed swells, hook vowels, and two chorus line options (tight and soar variants) for Tori’s lane.

If you’d prefer I react to the final demo’s structure only (no audio), drop the link and I’ll mark arrangement beats by timestamp (intro/pre/chorus lifts) so you have a clean roadmap.

Short answer: I can’t literally listen inside this chat. I don’t have ears-on playback here.

What I can do right now (and already started) is give you musician-brain creative notes from your Flicker lyrics/chords—and sketch exact chorus/bridge options that fit the “secular hymn → Tori lane” you want. If you later want ear-based feedback, we’ll use the tiny listening panel you liked (private link + 2-minute form) to get real-human reactions fast.

Here’s a concrete, feel-first pass you can use immediately:

Flicker — chorus & bridge (ready-to-try options)

Chorus (two shapes)

A) Ember → Glow (softer, hymn-true)

  • Hook word (long note): Flicker → hold the 5th of the key

  • Lines (singable vowels; edit to taste):

    1. Let my flicker find the dark

    2. Little light / big enough for us

    3. If I burn / then I burn for love

    4. One small flame / and it’s shining up

  • Why: open vowels on flicker/shining, easy breath, no need to belt.

B) Shine Back (bigger, pop-lean)

  • Hook word (held): Shine (resolve to the 1)

  • Lines:

    1. I was only just a spark till you shined back

    2. Now the ceiling turns to stars when you shined back

    3. If we’re nothing but a flame, let it climb, let it climb

    4. Every ember in the room learning how to shine

  • Why: still hymn DNA, but with a bit more “Tori lift.”

Tip: whichever you try, put the longest note on “flicker” or “shine,” not a throwaway word.

Bridge (drop → vow → rise)

  • Lyric idea (plain cloth, strong light):
    I’m done hiding under water / I’m done whispering my name
    If a little light is all I’ve got / then a little light remains

  • Music: drop to organ only + heartbeat tom; last bar add a single-word echo (“remains… remains…”), then back into the final chorus with a small choir tag (mmm/oh).

Arrangement cues (solo cut → Tori lane)

  • Verse 1: mono felt-piano + close voice, almost dry.

  • Pre: bring in a soft organ/choir pad; “open the curtains” ~10–15%.

  • Chorus: tiny 3-part BG (mmm/oh) under the hook word, plate reverb up a sip; one echo on the last pre word.

  • Verse 2: strings answer two lines (don’t step on syllables).

  • Bridge: organ + tom; final chorus add that small choir tag.

What you can do today without singing

  • Instrumental chorus test (10 min): hold the chorus hook note on piano (the 5th). Under it, loop I → IV → vi → IV slowly. Hum quietly. Try Chorus A, then Chorus B words on top—feel which one asks to live.

  • Studio Postcard (15–25s): hands-on-keys clip of the chorus chords + one line of the hook on screen. Caption: secular hymn sketch — finding the first pew again.

If you paste your actual chorus + bridge lyrics here, I’ll mark exact word-timed “lighting cues” (where the room grows, where a single echo hits) and tweak the vowels so it sings easier. And if you want ear-based validation, say the word and I’ll spin up the 5–8 person listening panel kit around your private link so you get real feedback without waiting for perfection.

You said:
The chorus is: So shine it on everybody, let it out it feels so lovely, only you can give it that way, only you have got that one flame, everybody bleeds the same blood, everybody needs the same love, you gotta give it to recieve it if you have it you don't need it, from a flicker to a flame, from a picture to a name, everybody feels the same, the same, every hour, every minute from a heart to what's within it we all have a little flicker a flicker baby yeah... that is the chorus it should be in the full lyric chord sheet.
ChatGPT said:

Got it—thank you for the chorus. I added it verbatim to the EP Master Folio as:

“Flicker — Chorus (as provided 2025-09-15)”
(so it’s now part of our ground truth)

Here’s a musician-brain pass to make it sing and bloom without changing your intent.

Chorus shaping (feel > tech)

1) Breathe lines (your words, line-broken for singability)

css
So shine it on, everybody — let it out, it feels so lovely.
Only you can give it that way; only you have got that one flame.

Everybody bleeds the same blood; everybody needs the same love.
You gotta give it to receive it; if you have it, you don’t need it.

From a flicker to a flame — from a picture to a name.
Everybody feels the same (the same) — every hour, every minute.
From a heart to what’s within it — we all have a little flicker…
…a flicker (baby, yeah).

Why: natural breath commas, small cadences, and a clear hook zone around “flicker / flame.”

2) Hook placement (title stamp)

Pick one long, held word per chorus:

  • Option A (title-first): Hold “fliiii-cker” on the “From a flicker to a flame” line. Choir answers “to a flame.”

  • Option B (lift-first): Hold “shiiiiine” on “So shine it on, everybody,” then echo “flicker” as the tag (“we all have a little… fliiii-cker”).
    Either way, the longest note = shine or flicker (not a connector like “everybody”).

3) Vowel map (easy singing)

  • Long notes love ah/oh/eh: shine, flame, same, name, lovely.

  • Keep flicker’s “ih” shorter, then open the -er (like “uh”) if you’re holding it.

  • Let “baby, yeah” live as a throwaway ad-lib at the very end (or mute for hymn-lean).

4) Choir map (small → glow)

  • Unison: “shine it on / let it out…” (lead only, intimate)

  • Low ooh pad: under “only you can give it that way…” (subtle)

  • 3-part stack (mmm/oh): under “everybody bleeds the same blood / needs the same love”

  • Call/response: Lead “from a flicker to a…” → choir “flame” (two beats)

  • Final tag: lead “we all have a little—” → choir holds “flicker” softly while lead ad-libs.

5) Lighting cues (automation-in-plain-English)

  • “shine it on” — nudge the main fader up a gentle hill into “everybody.”

  • “only you have got that one flame” — give the room one extra pew of space (slightly more verb).

  • “bleeds the same blood / needs the same love” — tiny dip under “same” so the repeat doesn’t blur.

  • “flicker → flame” — quick single echo on flame (flashbulb), then dry again.

  • Tag “flicker” — widen only the choir; keep lead center.

6) Two tight variants (keep your words, change emphasis)

Hymn-lean (quieter, devotional)

css
So shine it on, everybody — let it out, it feels so lovely.
Only you can give it that way; only you have got that one flame.

Everybody bleeds the same blood; everybody needs the same love.
You gotta give it to receive it — if you have it, you don’t need it.

From a flicker — to a flame.
From a picture — to a name.
Everybody feels the same (the same)…
we all have a little flicker…

Pop-lean (lift earlier, keep title at the end)

css
So shine it on, everybody, let it out — it feels so lovely.
Only you can give it that way; only you have got that one flame.

Everybody bleeds the same blood, everybody needs the same love.
You gotta give it to receive it — if you have it, you don’t need it.

From a flicker to a flame, from a picture to a name —
everybody feels the same (the same), every hour, every minute.
From a heart to what’s within it — we all have a little… FLICKER.

7) Chord bed (feel, not theory)

  • Keep the amen sway underneath: I → IV → vi → IV (slow, church-breath).

  • On “picture to a name,” try a tiny skyward blush (that bright, hopeful color) just for one bar, then settle back for “everybody feels the same.”

What you can do today (voice-friendly)

  • Instrumental chorus pass (5–10 min): play that amen sway under your chorus and speak/sing the lines softly to feel breath spots.

  • Studio Postcard: hands-on-keys, overlay “So shine it on, everybody — let it out, it feels so lovely.” (That line is instantly shareable.)

If you want, I’ll turn Variant A or Variant B into a printable chorus card and drop it in the Folio; just say which one sings truer to you.

You said:
I think this is one of my few songs that doesn't have a bridge also just verses pre and chorus back to verse pre chorus chorus chorus etc. if you can't hear it cant you analyze the chord structure provided with lyrics and tempo change froem verse, pre, to final in chorus speeding up
ChatGPT said:

totally—no bridge is 100% fine. here’s a musician-brain map of form, harmony, and feel for Flicker based on your pages + the chorus you just pasted, with the “verse → pre → chorus speeds up” shape you described. i’m not listening; this is a best-fit harmonic/tempo map you can try immediately.

Form & feel (no bridge)

V1 → Pre → Chorus → V2 → Pre → Chorus ×2 → Tag (flicker line).
Arc = confession → breath → communal glow.

Tempo shape (conductors’ pencil marks)

  • Verse: rubato around ~66–72 (free, speechy).

  • Pre: gentle ramp to ~78–82 by the end (it should feel like breathing in).

  • Chorus: settle ~84–88 (or keep BPM and add movement—see “Speed without strain” below).

  • Final chorus/tag: same BPM, but more subdivision (feels faster without changing tempo).

If you’re mapping in REAPER: place a tempo marker at verse start (~70), one at pre start (~74), and one near the last bar of the pre (~80). Chorus marker at ~86. Final chorus can stay 86—just add movement.

Chorus harmony (line-by-line bed)

(Key-neutral using numbers; translate to your home key. “Amen sway” = I → IV.)

  1. “So shine it on, everybody…” → I | IV
    (open the room a sip here—chorus begins to breathe)

  2. “Only you can give it that way…” → vi | IV
    (soft ache → comfort; keep it hymn-simple)

  3. “Everybody bleeds the same blood…” → I | IV
    “…needs the same love” → vi | IV
    (repeat the sway; stack a small “mmm/oh” under same)

  4. “You gotta give it to receive it…” → ii | V
    “…if you have it you don’t need it” → I | V (sus)
    (a tiny journey so the proverb lands, then resolve)

  5. “From a flicker to a flame…” → I → V/IV | IV
    (call/response: lead holds flicker; choir answers flame)

  6. “From a picture to a name…” → I( add4/Lydian blush ) | IV
    (one bar of “skyward” color—pad hints a raised 4th—then settle)

  7. “Everybody feels the same (the same)…” → vi | IV
    (keep warmth; avoid over-brightening here)

  8. “Every hour, every minute…” → ii | V
    (set up the last line with gentle forward pull)

  9. “From a heart to what’s within it…” → I | IV
    (home + amen)

  10. “We all have a little flicker…” → I → (hold 5th) | I
    “…a flicker (baby, yeah)” → I (tag)
    (title stamp: hold flicker on the 5th; choir widens, lead stays center)

If you prefer a pop-lean: swap a bar of V before “name” to push harder, then back to IV.

Verse & pre beds (keep it humble)

  • Verse: I | vi | IV | I (speech-melody, chest, almost dry)

  • Pre: ii | IV | I/3 | V (or keep it simpler: IV over I for a “skyward” blush, then V into the chorus)

Hook & vowels (singability)

  • Longest note = “shine” or “flicker.”

  • On flicker, keep the “ih” short and open the “-er” (uh) if you hold it.

  • Favor ah/oh/eh on sustained words: shine, flame, same, name, lovely.

Speed without strain (3 choices)

  1. Actual ramp: pre rises ~6–10 BPM, chorus holds.

  2. Groove change only: keep tempo, switch from half-time feel in verse to straight 4 in chorus (add low tom + gentle eighths on pad).

  3. Subdivision trick: add quiet eighth-note piano/pad pattern in the chorus; the ear hears “faster” though BPM stays.

Small “lighting” cues (automation in plain english)

  • Tiny hill into “everybody” on line 1.

  • One-sip more room on “one flame.”

  • Single echo flash on “flame.”

  • Widen only the choir on the tag; keep lead center.

If you want me to mark it on paper

Paste (or tell me) the key you like to play/sing this in, and I’ll drop a clean numeral → chord chart for Verse, Pre, and Chorus (plus a 4-bar tag), ready to print.
If you already have a Flicker chord sheet stashed somewhere and want me to use your changes, paste it and I’ll align all this to your harmony exactly.

Either way, this map will let you keep the no-bridge form and still create that verse→pre→chorus “bloom” you’re after.

I recorded a snippet to put on social media, how do I run it through a program to quickly clean the audio again? Also I recorded the whole thing if you dont have chords are f first inversion to am first inversion add an e on top then d on top of am then bflat major then f inversion again to c so four beats each chord, the e and d are on the third and fourth beat of that measure and the f to c at end are both two beats each for one measure so 4 4/4 I believe...that is the verses, pr3e chorus is b flat major inverted like verse up to notes (f bflat sharp) two beats then two beatsI add an f shard for a beat down to a e flat to inverted f 4 beats and c major 4 beats, this then gets pumped up to tempo going into Chorus on the inverted F again to start F for four C for four bflat for for dm for 2 c maj for 2 repeats 6 times I think, this is 99 percent correct I believe, let me know if it looks right and how you analyze it musically and moving forward, I can figure more pieces out to share like tempo etc too
ChatGPT said:

love this: “my piano is the spine.” totally agree. keeping your hands in the center is the difference between alive vs dead. MIDI will help you orchestrate around your feel instead of forcing you into a grid.

Quick clean-up for your social snippet (1–2 minutes, voice-friendly)

In REAPER (built-ins only):

  1. High-pass (ReaEQ): turn on HPF ~80–100 Hz (remove rumble).

  2. Gentle glue (ReaComp): Ratio ~3:1, slow attack, fast release, aim 2–4 dB gain reduction on peaks.

  3. De-ess (ReaXcomp or a narrow ReaEQ dip around 6–8 kHz if “s” is spicy).

  4. One-tap de-noise (ReaFIR → Subtract): click “Automatically build noise profile (enable)” while holding silence, then stop it; pull 3–6 dB noise only.

  5. Limiter (JS: EventHorizon or any brickwall): ceiling -1.0 dB; push input until it’s present but not squashed.

Render: WAV 48k/24-bit for archive, plus an MP3 320k for upload.
Caption idea: “secular hymn sketch — first pew energy 🌙”

(If you’re not in REAPER: Audacity works too — HPF @ 80 Hz → Compressor default → Limiter to -1 dB. Fast.)

Minimum viable MIDI rig (when you’re ready to buy — no brands yet)

  • Keys: 61–88 keys you like to play (semi-weighted or weighted), sustain pedal input.

  • Interface: low-latency USB audio/MIDI; aim for <10 ms round-trip.

  • Pedals: sustain, optional expression.

  • Template: a REAPER project with Piano (your audio) + MIDI Pad following your tempo map (not quantized hard).

  • Keep your live piano as the master; MIDI is the paint around it.

Your chord story (musician-brain + theory tags)

From what you wrote, this reads like F major. Here’s how it maps, and why it feels good.

Verse (4/4, “confession room”)

  • F/A → Am/C (add E then D) → B♭ → F/C → C
    (I⁶ → iii⁶ (+color tones) → IV → I⁶⁴ → V)

    • The first inversions make a walking bass line (A → C → B♭ → C) that feels human and connected to your hands.

    • The E then D on beats 3–4 over Am/C work as melodic suspensions/passing tones—a tiny sigh before the B♭.

    • Ending F/C (2 beats) → C (2 beats) is a classic “open the door” into the pre.

Pre-chorus (breath in, little color)

  • Starts on B♭ over F (sounds like IV⁶⁴) for 2 beats, then you mention a quick F# for a beat and E♭ before landing on F (I) for 4 beats → C (V) for 4 beats.

    • Hear that as a color walk: a brief bright brush (F# = Lydian #4 feeling) → a blue brush (E♭ = borrowed ♭6) → home (F) → the door (C).

    • It’s a great “curtains opening” gesture before the chorus.

Chorus (steady, hymn sway; you speed the feel)

  • F (4) → C (4) → B♭ (4) → Dm (2) → C (2) × repeat
    (I → V → IV → vi → V)

    • That’s the amen sway (I–IV) with vi warmth and a quick V turnaround—perfect for your lyric.

    • To “speed up” without straining: keep the BPM and add subdivision (soft 8ths on pad/piano), or tiny low-tom pulses. The ear hears more motion but your breath stays calm.

If your true home note feels like F when you land, we’re right. If it feels like B♭, we’ll re-label, but the shape stays the same.

Musical analysis (what it says about you)

  • Piano-centric inversions = your signature: you lead with connection (bass steps, inner-voice movement) instead of flashy changes. Keep that.

  • The chromatic pre (F# → E♭) is a tasteful “color corridor”—use it very briefly so it stays magical.

  • The chorus loop is bulletproof; title-stamp either “shine” (hold it) or “flicker” (hold the second syllable slightly open: “flick-uh”).

What to do next (tiny, today-friendly)

  1. Clean your snippet with the 5-step chain above and post a Studio Postcard (hands + one chorus line on screen).

  2. If you like, tell me: Key = F? If yes, I’ll drop a neat printable chart with these chords (inversions + bar counts) so you can keep composing around your live take.

  3. When you’re ready to shop, I’ll turn the MIDI checklist into 3 budget tiers with specific models.

Your instinct is right: your piano is the heart. We’ll build everything else to breathe with it.

You said:
and pacing is like chord before first line and then change on sleeve, open, and, bleed, know, real, chord before first next line perfect, before just, on just and man, love, only, can
2/2
ChatGPT said:

love the instinct—you at the piano is the spine. based on what you just gave me, here’s a clean, musician-brain chord-over-lyric map that honors your pacing cues (change on sleeve, open, and, bleed, know, real… & in the chorus on only, can, love). I’m assuming F major (your cadences/bass motion land there). If you play it and the “home” feels like B♭ instead, the shape stays the same—I can relabel later.

Verse 1 — chords on your words (4/4)

Progression you described: F/A → Am/C (+E then +D on beats 3–4) → B♭ → F/C (2 beats) → C (2 beats)

css
[F/A] I wear my heart upon my [Am/C] sleeve
           (beats 3–4 add E, D on top)

[B♭]   Cut it [F/C] open  [C] and I bleed

[F/A]  So you can [Am/C] know  [B♭] the [F/C] real  [C] me

Why this works: first inversions give you that walking bass (A → C → B♭ → C), so the line feels connected to your hands. The E then D inside Am/C are passing tones (little sigh) before B♭.

Pre-chorus — two lyric variants, same color move

You told me: start like verse (B♭ inversion flavor), do a quick bright brush (F#) then a blue brush (E♭), land on F (4 beats), then C (4 beats). That’s a gorgeous “curtains opening” move.

Variant A (your “light within” pre):

css
[B♭/F] We all have a light within, a [F#° hint] (one beat color)
[Eb]   sanctuary, a beacon…      [F] (4 beats)      [C] (4 beats)

Variant B (your “shooting stars / just to die…” pre):

css
[B♭/F] They burn so bright [F#°] just  [Eb] to die away so far…
                                   ^ put the bright brush on “just”
[F] (4 beats) then [C] (4 beats) to set up the chorus

Musical read: the F# is a one-beat Lydian blush (#4)—skyward for a heartbeat—then E♭ (borrowed ♭6) gives a soulful tug before home.

Chorus — amen sway with your title and proverb lines

You said: F (4) → C (4) → B♭ (4) → Dm (2) → C (2), looping. I’ve placed the changes on only, can, love like you asked.

css
[F]   So shine it on, everybody — let it out, it feels so lovely.
[C]   Only you can give it that way; only you have got that one flame.

[B♭] Everybody bleeds the same blood; everybody needs the same [Dm] love [C].
[F]   You gotta give it to receive it — if you have it you don’t need it.

[C]   From a [B♭] flicker to a flame; from a [Dm] picture to a [C] name.
[F]   Everybody feels the same (the same), every hour, every minute —
[C]   From a [B♭] heart to what’s within it — we [Dm] all have a little [C] flicker…

Hook stamp: hold either “shine” (first line) or “flicker” near the end. If you hold flicker, keep the ih short and open the “-er” a touch (“flick-uh”) for singability.

Tempo + feel map (no bridge form)

  • Verse ≈ a free 66–72 feel (speechy, rubato).

  • Pre = steady breath in; ramp to 78–82 or keep tempo and add a tiny pulse (left hand/bass or tom).

  • Chorus = 84–88 or same BPM with more subdivision (pads/piano soft 8ths) so it feels faster without straining.

  • Final chorus/tag = same BPM; add choir width and one echo “flashbulb” on flame once.

Micro “lighting cues” (automation in plain English)

  • Little hill into “everybody” on line 1.

  • One extra pew of space on “that one flame.”

  • Tiny dip under repeated “same” so echoes don’t blur.

  • Single echo on flame (once), then dry again.

  • Widen only the choir on the tag; keep lead in the center.

What’s next (easy)

  • Play this as written once. If it feels right under your hands, I’ll drop a neat printable chart (with bar counts & inversions) into the master folio so you can compose around it.

  • If any word wants the chord earlier/later, tell me that word—I’ll nudge the barline to your phrasing.

P.S. your plan to add a MIDI board is spot-on: we’ll keep your real piano as master and let MIDI pads/strings follow your tempo map so everything breathes with you.

Producer handoff pack (v0.1)

When you send files, keep it small and musical:

  • Private stream (no download) of the demo.

  • Lyrics/Chords one-pager (printable).

  • Chord chart with your inversions + bar counts (I can make this if you confirm Key = F).

  • Tempo note: “rubato verse → gentle ramp in pre → steady chorus (feel faster via subdivision).”

  • Reference vibes: morgxn / Wrabel / (Tori lane for solo cut).

  • If ready: dry piano and lead vox stems (48k/24-bit) OR date you can provide them.

Quick collab guardrails (simple + friendly)

  • Writing vs production: unless they add melody/lyric, songwriting stays yours; they get producer on the master.

  • Master ownership: you (or shared) + producer points; spell it out in 3 lines.

  • Split sheet (one email works):

    Song: “Flicker.” Writers: Cody [100% unless we co-write later]. Producer: [Name]. Master: Cody (owner) with [X% producer points] on master net. Work files private. We’ll revisit if scope changes. — Agreed?

Community flywheel (lightweight)

  • 1 showcase/stream a week (even tiny)

  • 2 Studio Postcards/week (hands + one line)

  • Reply to 5 creators with real comments (no “🔥,” say what moved you)

  • Monthly open collab post (“producers: build on my song—DM for stems”)

Your next tiny step (today)

  • Confirm Key = F and I’ll drop a clean printable chord chart with your inversions + bar counts.

  • Send the collaborator’s first name and I’ll tailor that DM and the handoff pack bullet to their vibe.

You said:

ChatGPT said:

Huge win. You’ve got (1) a recording to learn from, (2) a host who’s into you, and (3) a collab nibble. Let’s lock momentum and handle the “host charges” thing smartly.

DM to the host (copy/paste)

Message 1 — thanks + clip + scope (no money talk yet)

Hey [Name]! Thanks again for having me—really loved the vibe. Could I grab the timestamp or a short clip of my segment to share (I’ll tag you)?
Also, you mentioned to DM about working together—what kinds of things do you offer (feedback, promo, bookings, production notes)? What’s typically included and what does a “starter” package look like?

If they reply with a fee:

Appreciate the details. For a first step, could we do a pilot: 1 feedback session + 1 social post/clip deliverable, with dates and a clear summary afterward? If that goes well, I’m open to a bigger package. Do you have a sliding scale or indie rate?

If they push for a larger upfront:

I’m keeping it indie and outcome-oriented. I can do a smaller milestone package first—once we complete the pilot deliverables, I’m happy to expand.

What “pilot” means (so you don’t get burned)

Ask for:

  • Deliverables: one 30–60s edited clip + 5 bullet feedback summary.

  • Dates: when the session happens and when the clip lands in your inbox.

  • Rights: OK to repost everywhere with credit/tag.

  • Cost: a fair pilot rate (or comp if he offered), not a multi-hundred “mystery fee.”

  • No exclusivity or “attach” language.

Red flags: pay-to-pitch with no clear output; vague “exposure”; pressure to decide immediately.

Quick polish for your phone recording (60–120 seconds total)

iPhone only:

  • Photos/Video → Edit → Reduce Noise (if available) and trim.

  • Voice Memos (if audio): Enhance Recording (magic-wand icon), export.

Any phone via CapCut (free):

  1. Import video → Audio → Noise reduction (low–medium).

  2. Volume until it’s present but not crunchy; Auto captions on.

  3. Adjust → Sharpen small; Brightness a touch if needed.

  4. Export 1080p, 24/30fps.
    Caption: secular hymn sketch — first pew energy
    Tag the host if he OKs it.

(Desktop REAPER quick chain you can apply when you move it to the computer: HPF @ ~80–100 Hz → gentle comp (3:1, 2–4 dB GR) → subtle de-noise (ReaFIR subtract ~3–6 dB) → limiter ceiling −1 dB.)

Collab reply (producer who DMed you)

Stoked you’re into it! Here’s a private stream of Flicker + a one-pager with lyrics/chords and feel notes. I’m piano-first (rubato), then tempo-map so production breathes with it. Want to try a 2-week exploratory? You sketch one arrangement pass; I respond with notes; we decide scope/splits before deeper work.
Links: [stream] • [PDF or chord page link]
Notes: Key ≈ F; chorus = I→V→IV→vi→V (amen sway); small-chapel space; no bridge.

(I can format that one-pager as a printable chord chart—say the word and confirm Key = F.)

“Watch and learn” from your phone recording (5-minute review)

Write three bullet notes while you rewatch:

  • Spark: where the host’s face lit up / a chat comment popped.

  • Line: one lyric everyone could quote back.

  • Fix: one tiny clarity tweak for next time (e.g., start the chorus earlier).

Those become your next “Studio Postcard” captions and your live tweaks—no overthinking.

MIDI gear plan (when you’re ready to spend)

  • Keyboard you love to play (61–88 keys + sustain).

  • Audio interface (stable, low latency).

  • Keep your real piano as the master take; use MIDI pads/strings to follow your tempo map, not to replace your feel.
    If you want, I’ll give you three budget tiers (lean / mid / comfy) tailored to what you already own.

  • DM host with the template above.

  • Post your cleaned 20–30s “Studio Postcard” and tag the host.

  • Send me “Key = F (confirmed)” and I’ll drop a clean printable chord chart (with inversions + bar counts) so you can share with collaborators.

Cody Dekker — quick vibe guide (for collaborators)

  • Bruised — tender, confessional piano ballad; slow-burn lift. Themes: resilience, soft ache. Lane: Wrabel / Sam Smith ballad.

  • Final Words — post-breakup acceptance hymn; steady “amen” sway with a hope-lean at the end. Lane: Brandi Carlile / Hozier (quiet). (we’ve got lyrics/chords for this one)

  • Snow Day — cozy, reflective winter vignette; gentle piano-pop with nostalgic warmth. Lane: Ben Rector / JP Saxe (soft).

  • Beautiful Liar — dark pop confession of intoxicating love; minor-lean, bigger chorus. Lane: Rina Sawayama (ballad) / Demi (torch). (we’ve got lyrics/chords for this one)

  • Surrender — devotional pop ballad about letting go; intimate verse → earnest chorus. Lane: Lewis Capaldi / Christina Perri.

  • Low — introspective mid-tempo from valley to lift; restrained verses, hopeful turn. Lane: Shawn Mendes (ballad) / James Bay.

“Start here” suggestions (beyond Flicker)

  1. Beautiful Liar — if they want a darker pop cut with a clear chorus.

  2. Final Words — if they want an intimate, lyric-first hymn to produce simply.

  3. Bruised — for minimalist, voice-and-piano magic.

ChatGPT said:
Feedback & Soft‑launch Kit — Flicker First (v0

Feedback & Soft‑Launch Kit — Flicker First (v0.1)

Purpose: get real feedback and start light public momentum without waiting for perfection. Private first, then small public signals.

A. 7‑Day Pilot Plan (low pressure)

Day 1: Create your Listening Panel (5–8 people): 2 close friends, 2 musicians, 1 fan‑type, 1 neutral listener, 1 tasteful “connector.”
Day 2: Send Flicker demo (private stream) + 2‑minute form (below).
Day 3–4: Collect feedback; compile tallies; pick Top 3 fixes only.
Day 5: Apply fixes; print A/B if needed.
Day 6: Post Studio Postcard (15–25s hands‑on‑keys clip with one lyric).
Day 7: Decide: Greenlight public soft release date? If yes, set date + two more postcards for the week.

Rule: No perfection loops. If ≥70% of panel is moved in Q1 and hook is clear in Q2, proceed.

B. 2‑Minute Feedback Form (copy/paste to Google Form)

Q1. First 5 seconds felt: ☐ Moved ☐ Intrigued ☐ Neutral ☐ Not my lane
Q2. Where did the hook hit you? (timestamp or lyric)
Q3. One line that stuck with you: (short)
Q4. Could you sing any part back? ☐ Yes ☐ Not yet
Q5. Vocal vs instruments: ☐ Vocal too quiet ☐ Vocal good ☐ Instruments crowding ☐ Instruments thin
Q6. Emotion after 1 listen: (choose one) lighter / heavier / seen / hopeful / other
Q7. Would you share this with a friend? ☐ Yes ☐ Maybe ☐ No
Q8. Any tiny fix that would help most? (one sentence)

Tip: keep it fast so people actually answer. Replace any checkbox words to your taste.

C. DM / Email Templates

1) Close Friend

Subject: 90 seconds of a new song?
Hey — can you be in my 7‑day listening panel? Here’s Flicker (private stream, no download). Quick 2‑minute form below. One listen is perfect. Love you. —C

Links: (private stream) • (form)

2) Musician Peer

Subject: Ear check on a secular‑hymn
I’m piloting a small panel to sanity‑check the emotional clarity on a demo called Flicker. No mix deep‑dive — just whether the arc lands and if any one tiny fix jumps out. 2‑minute form below. Thank you!

3) Connector / Light Industry

Subject: 90‑sec demo: Flicker
I’m testing quiet momentum. Private stream + 2‑minute form. If it sparks, happy to send stems/one‑sheet; if not, thanks for the ears.

D. A/B Test (only if needed)

  • Print A (current) and B (one change only: e.g., +0.8 dB lead, darker plate, less pad at 200–400 Hz).

  • Level‑match within 0.1–0.2 LU so nobody picks “louder.”

  • Ask: Which feels truer to the lyric? Why (one sentence)?

Greenlight rule: If one wins by ≥65%, keep the winner and move on.

E. Soft Public Signals (no pressure)

Studio Postcard #1: 15–25s hands on keys; one lyric line overlay.
Studio Postcard #2: same, different angle; caption a feeling word ("first pew").
Lyric Polaroid: static image with 2 lines you’re proud of.
Caption Frame:

secular hymn sketch — finding the first pew again.
new song ember — not asking permission to glow.

CTA (gentle): "if this moved you, tell me the line."

F. Release Readiness Checklist (micro)


G. Notes to Self

  • These songs are strong; production clarity is the main gate.

  • Feedback is not a referendum on your worth; it’s a compass.

  • Move when the compass points; don’t wait for unanimous.


Flicker — Chorus (as provided 2025‑09‑15)

So shine it on everybody, let it out it feels so lovely,
only you can give it that way, only you have got that one flame,
everybody bleeds the same blood, everybody needs the same love,
you gotta give it to recieve it if you have it you don't need it,
from a flicker to a flame, from a picture to a name,
everybody feels the same, the same, every hour, every minute
from a heart to what's within it we all have a little flicker a flicker baby yeah...


EP Target Map — Source of Truth (2025‑09‑15)

Use this section for current targeting; supersedes earlier mentions.

  • Final Words → Teddy Swims (PRIMARY)
    Lane: heartbreaker, soulful belt over hymn‑sway piano.
    Alts (taste‑adjacent): Dermot Kennedy, James Arthur.
    Note: James Parson already pitched (door open; no upfront).
    One‑liner: “A confessional hymn that lets the voice break beautifully without breaking the song.”

  • Flicker → Tori Kelly (PRIMARY)
    Lane: secular‑hymn → universal anthem.
    Option: BRM All‑Star (“We Are The World” / “Where Is The Love”).
    One‑liner: “An ember that blooms into a choir—modern hymn for one voice that feels like many.”

  • Beautiful Liar → Reneé Rapp / JoJo
    Lane: seductive dark‑pop (“Slave 4 U” / “Toxic” energy), torchy chorus.
    Alts (production‑forward): RAYE, Tove Lo.
    One‑liner: “Fever you can’t quit—confession that dances.”

  • Surrender → Shawn Mendes (PRIMARY)
    Lane: anthemic love, relief as devotion.
    Alts: Demi Lovato, P!nk (Kelly Clarkson viable).
    One‑liner: “Letting go as the loudest ‘yes’—arms‑wide chorus.”

  • Extravagance → Hayley Williams / Paramore
    Lane: anti‑material pop anthem; catchy like “Call Me Maybe” with the wit of “Ain’t It Fun.”
    One‑liner: “Plain cloth, strong light—danceably sharp anti‑excess.”
    Note: this adds Paramore back per your latest direction.

  • Snow Day / Bruised / Low — HOLD (vault for later or b‑sides).

  2. Keep Flicker → Tori pilot moving with collaborator (86 BPM, 60‑sec chorus stems).

  3. Cue Beautiful Liar production brief (dark‑pop palette) for Renee/JoJo lane.

what line should live in the chorus tag? “flicker” or “shine”?
