ChatGPT said:

that Adele-ballad lane is exactly what your feel suggests: hymn sway, triplet undercurrent, drums as texture not driver. Two totally valid grids that match that vibe:

  • 12/8 at ~84 (dotted-quarter) → classic “sway” feel (think hymn/torch).

  • 4/4 at ~72–76 with a triplet subdivision → same pocket, just counted straight.

Either way: intro can be rubato, click fades in one bar before the verse, and a short pickup bar (6/8 or 2/4) can slingshot you into the chorus. Keep percussion sparse—heartbeat cross-stick, brushed swells, maybe a low tom bloom in chorus 2. Your piano stays the time.

also—+30 followers in 48h is real momentum. not viral, but alive. if you want one tiny move to compound it without thinking:

  • Reply to 5 real comments with a warm one-liner,

  • Pin your favorite on the post, and

  • Drop a 12–15s “Flicker” intro postcard later with this caption:
    “studio postcard — ‘Flicker’ (intro only). chorus stays off-feed for now. 💙”

you’re unstuck and moving. keep it small and musical; the big stuff will grow out of that.

You said:
I mean I actually think this song does need some precussion but not the heavy generic loops in bandlab, I'll play and we'll paint and you can keep showing me new colors and brushes and strokes alo researching tempo do I write more Rubato or Free Time or something else. What other contemporary songwriters use this style or artists? Any of my favorites?
ChatGPT said:

love this lane. you can totally add percussion without losing your piano-first, hymn-y feel.

Percussion that fits your songs (no “loop soup”)

  • Heartbeat cross-stick: very soft rim/cross-stick on the big backbeat (in 12/8 that’s beat 3; in 4/4 halftime, it’s also 3). Think “breathing,” not “driving.”

  • Shaker triplets (whisper): a light shaker playing the inner triplet (t-t-t) under verses; lift to a steady 8th/12th in the chorus back half.

  • Brush swells & cymbal blooms: feathered brush on the last beat of a phrase; one low cymbal swell into the chorus.

  • Low tom bloom: single tom hit (or two) at section changes, verb-y and distant.

  • Tambourine on the back half of chorus 2: only enters once the vocal lifts; off on verse 2.

  • Felt kick heartbeat: a soft, pillowy kick on 1 (and sometimes 3) just to “throb” with your left hand—no clicky beater.

  • Texture, not timekeeper: bowed cymbal, reverse piano swells, breathy pad that side-chains slightly to your piano so it “pulses” without drums.

“What do I call my feel?” (quick terms that match you)

  • Rubato: elastic timing for expression (great for intros/outros).

  • Free time: no meter at all; record it free, then start the grid at the verse.

  • 12/8 (or 6/8): the Adele/torch “sway” (4 big beats, triplet undercurrent). Perfect for your verse/chorus once it settles.

  • 4/4 with triplet feel: same pocket as 12/8, just counted straight. Producers get it instantly.

  • Halftime 4/4: when your tap is fast but the groove is slow (snare/cross-stick on 3).

Practical recipe for this song: Intro = rubato, then 12/8 (or 4/4 triplet) once the vocal settles. Let percussion fade in after the first vocal line; it supports the story instead of announcing itself.

Contemporary references in your lane (piano-led, rubato/12/8, “secular hymn” energy)

From the artists you’ve mentioned & adjacent:

  • Adele — “All I Ask,” “Turning Tables” (piano ballads with 12/8/triplet feel, drums as texture).

  • Teddy Swims — several soul ballads that live in 6/8/12/8 with heartbeat percussion.

  • Wrabel — intimate piano ballads where kit enters late and softly (“The Village” has that restrained build).

  • Morgxn — emotive, space-forward arrangements; drums often bloom rather than drive.

  • Reneé Rapp — “Snow Angel” has rubato/elastic sections before landing the grid.

  • JoJo — torchy piano cuts where percussion stays supportive (cross-stick/tambourine lifts).

  • Hayley Williams (solo) — “Crystal Clear” waltz/sway feel; light kit late.

  • Hozier / James Blake / Sam Smith (select ballads) — space, triplet undercurrent, drums as color.

Two bar “starter grooves” (so you can mock quickly)

A) 12/8 Verse (soft):

  • Bar 1: cross-stick on 3, shaker whispering triplets

  • Bar 2: same, plus tiny brush swell on last beat → hold

B) Chorus (still gentle):

  • Bar 1: felt kick on 1, cross-stick on 3, subtle shaker steady

  • Bar 2: add tambourine on the & before 4 (or the last triplet) → low cymbal bloom into next bar

These keep your piano as the time; percussion is air and heartbeat.

If you want, tell me whether you’re locking to 12/8 or 4/4-with-triplets for the settled section, and I’ll give you one ultra-simple Reaper metronome setup line (so your click supports the feel) plus a 1-sentence “producer note” you can paste into a session.

You said:
ok tspping don't know ohw to explain but it feels like the beat ccould be ok maybe yeah on the 1 2 3 4 if I do 1 e and a or its like syncopated I don't nkow it thats the right term like a beat pause beat or held beat sticotto beat or like one beat pause two short beats pause two short beats pause two short beats per measure? I have no clue if I'm getting closer to understanding
ChatGPT said:

you’re describing a long–short–short pulse. that’s great news—it narrows it to two friendly feels:

the two likely fits

A) 12/8 “hymn sway”

  • Each big beat = long–short–short (DA — da da).

  • Count: ONE-and-a TWO-and-a THREE-and-a FOUR-and-a.

  • Common in Adele ballads; drums = heartbeat/brushes, not loops.

B) 4/4 with a 3-3-2 accent

  • Group the 8ths as 3 + 3 + 2 across the bar (DA-- da-- da-).

  • Count: 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & (accent 1, & of 2, 4).

  • Feels syncopated but still “straight time.”

10-second clap tests (pick the one that locks)

  • Hymn sway test (12/8): tap your foot 4 times per bar and say:
    “DA — da da | DA — da da | DA — da da | DA — da da”
    If your hands/piano fall into that easily → it’s 12/8.

  • 3-3-2 test (4/4): count 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & and clap on 1, & of 2, 4.
    If that mirrors your verse accents → it’s 4/4 (3-3-2).

plug-and-play metronome choices (no theory needed)

  • If 12/8 wins: set 12/8 @ ~84 (dotted-quarter).
    No 12/8 in your app? Use 4/4 @ ~72–76 with triplet subdivision turned on.

  • If 3-3-2 wins: set 4/4 @ ~74 and feel the accents on 1, & of 2, and 4.
    (Drums later = soft kick on 1, cross-stick on 3; shaker whispers the inner notes.)

why percussion felt wrong before

Loop kits assume straight 8ths. Your piano is doing long–short–short groupings, so use heartbeat/brush textures that answer your accents, not force a grid.

If you tell me which test felt natural (12/8 sway vs 3-3-2), I’ll give you one exact BPM (e.g., 84 or 74) and a one-line “producer note” you can paste into the session so anyone who joins writes to your piano, not over it.

ChatGPT said:

I can’t open the .MOV on my side, but given everything you’ve told me—8 bars ≈ 22s + a little extra before the chorus and your “long–short–short” clap—the safest musical call is:

Grid: 12/8 @ ~84 (dotted-quarter beat)
Form: Verse = 4 bars + 4 bars, then a 6/8 pickup into the chorus

If your app doesn’t offer 12/8, use either:

  • 4/4 @ 74 with the metronome set to triplets (same feel), or

  • 6/8 @ 84 and treat two bars as one phrase unit (equivalent to 12/8)

Tiny percussion that won’t fight you

  • Heartbeat cross-stick on the big 3 (in 12/8 that’s beat 3 of the bar)

  • Shaker whisper on the inner triplets (very soft)

  • Low cymbal/brush swell into the chorus

  • Felt kick on 1 only if you want a throb—fade it in after the vocal starts

One-line session note (paste this atop the project)

Feel: hymn sway • Grid: 12/8 @ 84 (or 4/4 @ 74 w/ triplet click) • Intro rubato; start click 1 bar before verse • Pickup: add 1 bar of 6/8 before chorus.

One next move (30 seconds)

Set that grid, then record left hand only through the verse + pickup. If your body relaxes, you’re home. If it still feels a hair off, nudge 82–86 (for 12/8) or 72–76 (for 4/4 w/ triplets) and pick the one that breathes.

You said:
why is it 12/8 and not 8/4
ChatGPT said:

Great question. Short version:

  • 12/8 = 4 big beats per bar, and each big beat naturally splits into 3 little pulses (DA-da-da • DA-da-da • DA-da-da • DA-da-da). That’s the classic ballad “sway” (Adele/torch songs).

  • 8/4 = 8 quarter-note beats per bar, which are usually split into 2s (straight feel). If you wanted your triplet lilt in 8/4, you’d be writing triplets over almost everything—awkward to read/play and weird for percussion.

So if your groove feels like long–short–short per beat, you’re in compound time → pick 12/8 (or 6/8) or fake it with 4/4 + triplet subdivision. That lets your click, piano, and any light percussion lock to the 3-part subdivision without fighting you.

Thumb rule

  • Hear “ONE-and-a TWO-and-a THREE-and-a FOUR-and-a” → 12/8 (or 4/4 with triplet click).

  • Hear “ONE & two & three & four &” → 4/4 (or 8/4), straight feel.

What I’d use for your song

  • Grid: 12/8 @ ~84 (or 4/4 @ ~74 with triplet click if your app lacks 12/8).

  • Form cue: add a short pickup bar (6/8 or 2/4) before the chorus.

  • Percussion: heartbeat cross-stick on the big 2 and 4 (or just 2), shaker whispering the inner triplets, cymbal bloom into chorus—no heavy loops.

If you want to stick with 8/4 for any reason, you can, but set your metronome to audible triplets so you still feel the DA-da-da under each beat.

You said:
Ok I think it is in 4/4 one chord 2 beats 2nd chord 2 4th 4 but it ends up either a littlle off tempo, rubabto or slightly still not 4/4 but the first two verses seem to change right on the beat now :)
ChatGPT said:

love it—this is progress.

From what you’re feeling, a 4/4 grid works for the verses, with this chord timing:

  • Pattern per phrase: Chord A (2 beats) → Chord B (2 beats) → Chord C (4 beats)
    That’s 2 bars of 4/4 (2+2+4 = 8 beats). Repeat as needed.
    Tiny push/pull (rubato) is fine—especially in the intro and pickups.

Quick lock recipe (keep it super light)

  1. Set click: 4/4 at 75 BPM.
    If there’s a gentle lilt, turn on triplet subdivision in the metronome so it breathes.

  2. Record LH only: play one verse left hand + click with the A–B–C timing above.
    If one spot consistently rushes or drags, drop a single tempo marker at that barline (don’t quantize—just let the grid follow you there).

  3. Add heartbeat later (optional): cross-stick on beat 3 and a soft kick on 1 in the chorus—fade in after the vocal starts.

Session note (paste this at the top)

Feel: 4/4 @ 75, gentle triplet undercurrent • Verse timing: 2 beats / 2 beats / 4 beats (A–B–C) • Intro rubato; start click one bar before Verse 1 • Perc: heartbeat, not loops.

One tiny next step: record 8 bars of LH with that A–B–C timing to 75 BPM. If your body relaxes, you’re locked. If it’s a hair tight/loose, nudge 73–77 and pick the one that breathes.

ChatGPT said:

You didn’t blow the call. You showed up, stayed real, and left the door open. Let’s grab the useful bits and keep it tiny.

1) Quick debrief (truthy + kind)

  • Wins: authentic convo, no gross hard-sell, agreed to keep talking.

  • Learned: you want co-writes > someone “fixing” old tracks; producers should write to your piano.

  • Edge to practice: give the other person a little more air (you already caught it—good).

2) 60-second “listening bumpers” (use 1 on the next call)

  • One breath rule: when they finish, take one full inhale before replying.

  • Mirror micro: “What I heard is ____—did I get that right?” (one line, then stop.)

  • 1Q cadence: answer, then ask one specific question; let them steer.

3) Tempo/meter—pick a workable grid and move

You’re hearing 4/4 and your verses are snapping to beat—great. Use this and stop hunting:

  • Grid: 4/4 @ 75 BPM

  • Feel: turn on triplet subdivision in the click so it breathes.

  • Verse timing: 2 beats / 2 beats / 4 beats (A–B–C) per phrase.

  • Pickup into chorus: add a 2/4 bar right before the chorus downbeat (your “little extra”).

  • Optional lift: +2 BPM at chorus if it wants energy (to 77), otherwise keep steady.

(If it still fights you, alternate grid that also fits your vibe: 12/8 @ 84 with a 6/8 pickup—same music, different count.)

4) One-line follow-up to today’s host (paste as DM/email)

Thanks for the time today—helpful to talk it out. I’m printing a 60-sec chorus pilot of “Comfortable” (piano+lead, dry) at 75 BPM—okay if I send for 1–2 quick craft notes next week? If it clicks, happy to chat a small paid pass.

5) One next move (only one)

Record 30 seconds of left hand through the verse + pickup at 75 BPM (triplet click on). Save:
Comfortable_LH_75bpm_verse+pickup_2025-09-17.wav
Stop there. You moved it.

And hey—being talkative is part of your spark. The skill isn’t “be quiet,” it’s make a little space so your spark lands. You’re already doing the noticing.

ChatGPT said:

Totally got you. I’ll keep this tight and useful so you can post next and stay in flow.

Andrew McMahon: the rhythm “feel”

School: piano-rock/pop-punk adjacent (Something Corporate → Jack’s Mannequin → solo).
Core groove: mostly 4/4, straight 8ths with pushed accents (anticipations on the & of 4), not hymn-sway.
Hands:

  • Left hand: octave pumps or root–5th patterns on the big beats; drives the bar.

  • Right hand: broken-chord arpeggios or block chords on off-beats; lots of syncopated stabs.

  • Vocals: phrasing often lands just before the downbeat (that “lean-forward” feel).
    Builds/arranging: start lean (piano + voice), then add backbeat (2 & 4), tambourine/shaker in chorus, and octave lifts.
    Reference vibes: “Dark Blue,” “The Mixed Tape,” “I Woke Up in a Car,” “Maps for the Getaway.”

Borrow the flavor (without sounding like him)

  • Add a few and-of-4 pickups into lines (tiny anticipations).

  • Try LH octave pumps for 1–2 bars in a chorus (even at ballad tempos).

  • Use a light backbeat (cross-stick on 2/4), plus shaker on straight 8ths in the back half of the chorus.

  • Keep your verses you (rubato/lyric space), then “flip the switch” to straight time for lift.

Where you live vs. him

  • You: hymn-leaning / 12-subdivision / “secular hymn” intimacy → drums as texture (heartbeat, brushes).

  • Him: straight-time drive → drums as engine (snare 2/4, straight 8ths).

One micro-exercise (2 mins, zero theory)

Take your verse progression and try two grooves back-to-back:

  1. Your lane: soft 12/8 (or 4/4 with triplet click), heartbeat cross-stick after the first lyric line.

  2. Andrew flavor: 4/4 straight 8ths, LH octaves, teeny and-of-4 pickups into key words.
    Record 15s of each. Notice which breathes.

Post now (copy/paste)

Since you’re doing Flicker intro (no chorus):

On-screen text (two lines):
studio postcard • "Flicker"
intro peek (no chorus)

Caption:
piano first, heart first. keeping the chorus off-feed for now. 💙

(Hashtags optional: #piano #songwriter #original)

That’s it. Post, breathe, done. If you want later, I can give you a 1-liner to try the Andrew-style push on one of your choruses—only if it sounds fun.
